It is often too demanding bc many functions degenerate at infinity. But a "local" version implies linear convergence is the initial value is small enough. The only (but worrying) obstruction to global convergence is occasionally points can escape at +inf.

Nice to see pushback to the idea of positionality statements that has been spreading in psychology. https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/17456916221144988 All contructivist researchers of course disagree. But as constructivist approaches are in direct opposition to my philosophy of science, that is fine. I agree with the authors that positionality statements should not be part of science. If you want to use them, do so only after reflecting on whether they actually align with your philosophy of science.

title: Pretraining Language Models with Human Preferences

last_post.content:
this seems like a promising direction
---
RT @arankomatsuzaki
Pretraining Language Models with Human Preferences

Pretraining with human feedback results in much better preference satisfaction than standard LM pretraining followed by finetuning with feedback, i.e., learning and then unlearning undesirable behavior.

title: Unpriced climate risk and the potential consequences of overvaluation in US housing markets - Nature Climate Change

last_post.content:
Given that in such places as California the real estate industry has effectively climate-silenced the market with regard to sea level rise, this seems significant. The industry has craftily enrolled homeowners, who see their real estate as nest eggs and are thus willing to join in the deceit.

"Our results underscore the severity of the financial risks to current homeowners and municipalities posed by potentially widespread property price deflation."

#ClimateSilence

title: KDEformer: Accelerating Transformers via Kernel Density Estimation

last_post.content:
RT @aminkarbasi@twitter.com

Transformers are at the heart of recent breakthroughs in AI. However, exact computation of these models incurs quadratic time/memory complexities in sequence length, hindering the training of long- sequence models. Can we dramatically accelerate them?

title: BLIP: Bootstrapping Language-Image Pre-training for Unified Vision-Language Understanding and Generation

last_post.content:
Went back to BLIP (https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.12086) last night. When I first skimmed it, I focused on the part of the paper focused on bootstrapping captions, but the "Multimodal mixture of Encoder-Decoder" architecture is pretty cool.

It uses a structured architecture involving multiple encoder/decoders wherein some parts of the architecture take advantage of others (e.g. using the contrastive loss for hard example mining for the image-text matching loss).

#ilp #vlp #multimodal

Multimodal Deep Learning - New Book

Multimodal learning(MML) is one of the hottest areas in AI research these days. MML has advanced a lot in recent times. We've seen models that generate images from texts, robotic actions from language & images, etc.

From the January 4th issue of our newsletter...

*Language models as agent models*

Jacob Andreas argues that big language models can, at least in some very narrow situations, “model agency and communicative intent”, without being “in any general sense human-like”. His research and explanation make for a good case. The paper is clear, accessible, and an important read for anyone following language model debates. (28 min).

title: Linear Convergence of Gradient and Proximal-Gradient Methods Under the Polyak-Łojasiewicz Condition

last_post.content:
Polyak-Łojasiewicz inequality generalizes strong convexity, and a simple condition to ensure linear converge of gradient descent even for non-convex functions. You should read the very nice and clear paper of @MarkSchmidtUBC and collaborators about this!
https://arxiv.org/abs/1608.04636

title: Investigating Explainability of Generative AI for Code through Scenario-based Design

last_post.content:
🤔❓In many cases, people have lots of questions and try many informal experiments with the generative AI’s capabilities and limitations (https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.04903), although we’re only beginning to scratch the surface of what explainability means in the context of generative AI.
4/8

Recent research has shown how much the training corpus matters for AI-generation tools. Some of the visual generators have been shown to recreate cultural stereotypes and biases (see e.g. https://arxiv.org/pdf/2211.03759v1.pdf).

That will be true for text, too, and this article on using ChatGPT to create #wine marketing materials raises, for me, questions about how current wine lexical forms and norms — not always positive — will be perpetuated in the generated copy.

https://janeanson.com/chat-gpt-and-wine-extinction-level-event-for-wine-writers-and-sommeliers

#ai #risks #ethics #language_models #llms #paper

Our paper on the privacy practices of labor organizers won an "Impact Recognition" award at #CSCW2022!

Much like the current migration from Twitter, organizers worked around technical and social constraints about where they talk and with whom, and how to moderate community conversations.

But unlike the Twitter migration, they often did this with zero institutional knowledge, since few organizers had done this remotely before the pandemic!

title: Tuning computer vision models with task rewards

last_post.content:
RT @__kolesnikov__@twitter.com

Vision meets RL! We reveal that policy gradient can be used for tuning vision models to optimize complex metrics, such as mAP, PQ or “color diversity”, observing large performance boosts on tasks like object detection, panoptic segmentation, etc. https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08242

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/__kolesnikov__/status/1626546150579879936

We have seen that AI assistance can help people produce better-quality results (https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.07682) or produce those results faster (https://arxiv.org/abs/2102.12592).

We have now released v2.0 of the resulting quality-controlled dataset, thanks to the continued efforts of a small team of volunteers.

Now available: 4944258 monthly rainfall amounts from more than 15,000 locations across the UK!

https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.7554242

We take a similar approach as in the Leiden algorithm (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-41695-z). We consider a queue of nodes, pop a node off the queue to consider updating its label, and push its neighbours to the queue if we updated its label.

title: Large network community detection by fast label propagation

last_post.content:
One of the fastest algorithms proposed in the literature for community detection in networks is the label propagation algorithm (LPA).
Lovro Šubelj and I here propose a fast variant (FLPA) that is up to 700 times as fast.

preprint: https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.13338
publication: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-023-29610-z

"Contrary to how it may seem when we observe its output, an LM is a system for haphazardly stitching together sequences of linguistic forms it has observed in its vast training data, according to probabilistic information about how they combine, but without any reference to meaning: a stochastic parrot."

I considered worldviews as models of the world which of course depend on actions. A person who reads books has a different worldview than one who watches movies, for example. title: Theory of Mind May Have Spontaneously Emerged in Large Language Models

last_post.content: Figures from Kosinski (2023). Theory of Mind May Have Spontaneously Emerged in Large Language Models: https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02083

Academic jobs are typically unstable and highly competitive (pre-tenure).

How does this affect science quality?

"[H]igh turnover in academic institutions fosters cursory research and hinders thorough, long-term projects. Research projects often hit a dead end when researchers drop out because their contracts have expired. Methodological expertise, which often takes years to acquire, is lost when highly skilled researchers leave."

via https://doi.org/10.1038/s41562-022-01508-2
@academicchatter #AcademicChatter
